comments.body: Add `operator ==` and `get hashCode` methods.  _RenderSlider.theme compares SliderThemeData values with ==. Likewise for SliderTheme.updateNotify().
Heh.  Turns out that was the fix for the failing test on Travis too, and so I had already done it by the time I got to this comment. :-)
NICE
This would be a good place to point to the place where you explain how one would usually create a SliderThemeData.  I assume that's SliderThemeData.materialDefaults()
Yes.  Done.
sample code should be in a `## Sample code` section.
Done (in another PR)

i would probably call this `SliderThemeData.fromPrimaryColors`. The name `SliderThemeData.materialDefaults` sounds like a constant that has material defaults, not a method that computes values from other values.

Hmm. Ok, but the reason I called it that was because the opacities that it overrides the given colors with, and the shapes it assigns for the components are all from the Material spec.  This is also the method used to create the default theme for the Material ThemeData.
being from the material spec is implied, this is the material library. :-)
aw, the shapes can't lerp? :-( :-P

Sadly no.  They encompass a lot of behaviors that would have made lerping complex, so I decided to cut my losses and eliminate the lerpTo and lerpFrom.  Not that we can't add them, or add a subclass of SliderComponentShape that has them.
you might want to do an `identical()` test here first since there's so many subproperties and they're so often going to be identical.
OK, done.
these are inconsistently wrapped which is weird
I've already fixed this in my other PR.
NICE. This is much easier to read.
OK, then.  Line length of 200 it is. :-)
probably best to steer away from the term "baseline" when referring to text, since it has an existing precise meaning
Ooh, good point.
We could just enable this automatically when debugPaintSizeEnabled is enabled.

Nit: First sentence of dartdoc goes on it's own line. Alternatively you could change the . to a , and accomplish the same thing. 

https://www.dartlang.org/guides/language/effective-dart/documentation#do-start-doc-comments-with-a-single-sentence-summary

I am now wondering the comments on the abstract const constructors are useful in this class. Isn't this sort of thing implied by the language and the fact that its an abstract class constructor already?

Actually, I did make an issue: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/25672

for this. Since this was copied from the current pattern, I am going to leave it as is, then update the docs in a follow up PR to make them consistent
Nit: Same as above (first sentence is own paragraph).

See related comment on  #25672

 Since this was copied from the current pattern, I am going to leave it as is, then update the docs in a follow up PR to make them consistent

Optional/suggestion: I think the named parameters can be de-indented:

```
void paint(
  PaintingContext context,
  Offset center, {
  RenderBox parentBox,
  SliderThemeData sliderTheme,
  Animation<double> enableAnimation,
  bool isEnabled,
  bool onActiveTrack,
});
```

I know we don't use `dartfmt` in flutter, but this is what dartfmt would do here incase you were curious.

I also noticed you format it this way below so it's probably best to be consistent.
Done

Referring to the new slider parts (here and in the slider docs) without explaining what they're for and what they look like makes the API more difficult to understand than it should be. For example, what is the reader to expect of the slider's "overlayShape".

This is a pre-existing problem that's exacerbated by the changes from this PR. What's really needed is a one or two slider images with labels and arrows that identify the parts along with some text that explains their roles. 

Annotated diagrams are a new feature for flutter docs, see https://github.com/flutter/assets-for-api-docs/

This "lack of a diagram" problem can be corrected in a separate PR. 

SliderThemeData's doc needs to be updated to match the features added in this PR.
Updated to match current documentation pattern, and will follow up with a diagram
Here's where you explain what a "slider tick" is.  You might to define it once with a dartdoc template.
Done, will fine tune with https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/25672
Here's where you explain what a "slider track" is. You might to define it once with a dartdoc template.
Please add a debugFillProperties() test, like https://github.com/flutter/flutter/blob/master/packages/flutter/test/material/outline_button_test.dart#L274
Can this be a follow up PR, since there is no existing slider debugFillProperties  test, and this PR is already large?
Sure

I don't think it would be wise for the preferredSize of a slider to depend on its enabled state (and our sliders don't).

This parameter isn't needed.
Removed param from getPreferredRect

comments.body:
Defines the appearance of a slider's track.

The slider's thumb moves along the track and a discrete slider's tick marks appear below the track.
Done, but I modified the second sentence slightly
Mainly, not sure what is meant by "slider's tick marks appear below the track"
Trying to clarify how tick marks are aligned with the track rectangle.
What if overlayWidth > parentBox.size.width?

What if trackLeft + trackWidth > parentBox.size.width?  And etc.

Need a set of assertions here.
done
Tick marks are only displayed if ....

Why would isEnabled affect preferredSize?

https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/25008/files#r243106244

NICE. Please spread the truth about "overlay" around. Apparently it's rendered **behind** the thumb. In the abstract class doc you can always say something like "typically the overlay expands until it is bigger than the thumb".

Done, one of the TODOs above to make it to that the overlay actually paints on top of the thumb, since that is probably the more logical behavior when painting custom overlays. The default material overlay painter would also be updated to paint an annulus instead of a circle.
Why does this method have an isEnabled parameter?
In case a developer wants the track size for enabled/disabled to be different
Nice
👍 This may get even easier once this is updated to spec

De-indent by 2 spaces and add trailing comma:

```
final double tickMarkRadius = getPreferredSize(
  isEnabled: isEnabled,
  sliderTheme: sliderTheme,
).width / 2;
```
Done
What's the reason for not changing it to 10 already?
Going to do all breaking size/paint changes in a single PR
Got it.  Makes sense.

Is there a different gap property for enabled sliders? '

Might be good to explain somewhere: there's ordinarily no gap between the bottom of the thumb and the top of the track. Assuming that's true of course.
No gap for enabled sliders. I added some more docs and renamed to disabledThumbGapWidth so its even more clear what this gap is (its not top and bottom)
You need to identify which properties are to be set in each case.
Done
`getPreferredSize` and `paint` should probably be annotated with `@overrides` here.
add `@overrides` here too
Nice.
I think maybe specify the exact value here is better `ShowValueIndicator.never`
Any value thats not ShowValueIndicator.always could cause the thumb not to draw in certain cases. I could list them all?
hmm I don't think listing them all is ideal. I'm actually fine leaving this as-is.

creating other...?
fixed
assert sliderTheme != null etc.  Here and elsewhere.

The doc for the enabledThumbRadius property should admit that the default is 10
Done
What's the "-2" doing here (it seems odd to be subtracting 2 from a radians value)? It's OK to say that it was derived "experimentally" so long as we explain what effect it has.
It is the y value of the offset, it was experimentally to get the bottom lobe in the right place after adjusting the lobe radius
